title: TCS announces dividend, rise in India’s iPhone exports, & more

news.description: Net profit rose 10.98% to Rs 10,883 cr during the Oct-Dec 2022 quarter compared to the same quarter in 2021.Consolidated revenue was Rs 58,229 cr, up 19.11%.The company has declared an interim dividend of Rs 8 and a special dividend of Rs 67 per share.

news.title: Word of the day
news.description:
Collection Efficiency
Collection efficiency refers to the % of money a bank is able to get back as compared to the total loan amount.
A higher collection efficiency ratio (above ~95%) means that the bank is able to recover most of its loans (i.e. the borrowers are paying back their loans).
A lower ratio shows it is facing problems in getting back the money from its borrowers.

news.title: 6-day course
news.description:
Theme: tools to pick stocks
Day 1: Monday
There are many tools investors use to pick stocks. In this week’s course, we’ll explore some of these tools.
Screener
Screener is a tool that helps you filter stocks based on certain criteria.
For example, let’s say you want a few stocks that belong to the banking sector, have a market cap of greater than Rs 50,000 cr, and have a PE ratio of less than 30.
You can go to a stock screener and put in these conditions. The stocks that match will be displayed.
These are just a few examples. There are many filters in screeners — most stock investing platforms offer stock screeners.
Many investors also use screeners to look for new investment ideas.

news.title: Featured question
news.description:
"Is large cap funds and index funds are same?"
They can be similar. But they are not the same.
An index fund invests in an index — a list of stocks. Like, the 30 biggest companies (Sensex 30), the 50 biggest companies (Nifty 50), and so on.
In index funds, no fund manager makes the buy/sell/hold decision.
The stocks are bought and sold based on their weightage in the list (or index).
In case of an index fund tracking the 50 biggest stocks in India, the index fund will invest the highest in the biggest company’s stock, then the 2nd biggest, and so on.
Most index funds invest in large-cap stocks (100 biggest companies in India). But there can be an index fund investing in smaller companies also (mid-cap, small-cap, etc).
In large-cap mutual funds (not index funds), the decision to buy/sell/hold a stock is made by a fund manager. It is his/her wish.
The only rule they have to follow is that at least 80% of the money should be invested in large-cap stocks.
